title: The Blessing of Perspective
devotional:
Old Man Fitzwilliam, they called him. He sat every day on the same park bench, come rain or shine, watching the world go by. Most folks just hurried past, maybe offering a quick nod, but few truly *saw* him. One brisk March afternoon, a young woman named Clara, burdened by work and relationship woes, slumped onto the bench beside him. She didn't intend to speak, but a sigh escaped her lips, heavy with unspoken troubles.

Fitzwilliam, his face etched with years of wisdom, simply said, "Sometimes, the best view is the one you almost miss." Clara, intrigued, glanced around the park. Buds were swelling on the trees, a robin sang a cheerful tune, and a group of children shrieked with laughter as they chased pigeons. Ordinary moments, easily overlooked.

"I don't see it," Clara admitted, her voice laced with bitterness. "Everything feels…broken."

Fitzwilliam smiled gently. "Ah, but even broken things hold beauty. A cracked pot can still hold flowers. A faded photograph can still evoke cherished memories. And a broken heart…well, that makes room for more love than you ever thought possible."

He went on to tell her a story of his own life, filled with loss and hardship, yet punctuated by unexpected moments of grace and joy. Moments he almost missed, had he been too consumed by his pain. He spoke of the kindness of strangers, the comfort of nature, and the unwavering love of God, even in the darkest of times. He talked about how the rain makes the plants grow.

By the time Clara left the park, the setting sun cast a golden glow on the world. She didn't suddenly have all the answers, but a seed of hope had been planted. She realized that even amidst the brokenness, blessings surrounded her, waiting to be acknowledged. Fitzwilliam's quiet wisdom reminded her that blessings aren’t always grand pronouncements; sometimes, they are quiet whispers in the ordinary moments of life. To feel the blessing we often need to see it. It often starts with a small bit of awareness and gratitude.
image_description: A close-up of a blossoming tree branch with small, delicate white flowers against a blurred background of green foliage.
insights: Fitzwilliam's wisdom echoes the biblical principle of finding joy in the midst of trials. James 1:2-4 encourages us to 'Consider it pure joy, my brothers and sisters, whenever you face trials of many kinds, because you know that the testing of your faith produces perseverance. Let perseverance finish its work so that you may be mature and complete, not lacking anything.' This passage highlights the transformative power of challenges and the opportunity to discover blessings even in the midst of difficulty. Furthermore, the seemingly small and ordinary acts of kindness, like Fitzwilliam offering wisdom to Clara, are reflective of Jesus' teachings in Matthew 25:40, where He states, 'Truly I tell you, whatever you did for one of the least of these brothers and sisters of mine, you did for me.'
prayer: Heavenly Father, open my eyes to see the blessings that surround me, even in the midst of difficult circumstances. Help me to recognize the beauty in brokenness and to find joy in the ordinary moments of life. Give me the strength to persevere through challenges and the wisdom to share Your love and grace with others. Thank you for Your unwavering presence and for the countless blessings You bestow upon me each day. Amen.
reflection: What blessings have you overlooked in your life recently? How can you cultivate a greater sense of gratitude for the ordinary moments? How can you be a source of blessing to others today, like Old Man Fitzwilliam was to Clara?
